Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about the diversity of primates and many of the cool things about their lives. I also gained deeper understanding of evolution and scientific thinking.
We learnt how to understand ignorance. In other words, we learnt how to know what we don't know. We also learnt how analyze graphs, ask correct questions, skim scientific papers.

I learned how to interpret but also analyze the shortcomings of various graphs. I also learned the significance of making a hypothesis when doing experiments. The glory of the course was being able to compare non-human primates to humans and being able to apply our knowledge at the Bronx zoo.

I learned a lot about primate behavior and ecology, and also how to learn about the behavior of complex social mammals. I also learned how to conduct brief and calming mindfulness practices which is an excellent skill I greatly value and have been using before all of my stressful experiences!
I gained much more self confidence in science related fields through our study of research methods and scientific papers on primatology.

This course was not only about learning the content on the field of primatology but an investigation into fundamental concepts such as the definitions of theory, skepticism and hypothesis. I learned to question the literature when appropriate and to direct class focus to areas and questions that I was interested in.
I learned how to use an ethogram.
I learned how to read and analyze scientific papers critically.
types of monkeys
You really gain a lot of primate knowledge from this class. It definitely led me to appreciate non-human primates more. It also helped me to learn how to take science tests in a college context.
Learned the basics about non-human primate identification and behavior, and was given the opportunities to draw conclusions about what their existence means for human society.

I gained a general understanding of primate taxonomy (first half of the course largely spent on primate groups and evolution) and a sense for concepts surrounding the application of the socioecological model and the complexity of natural selection to primates (second half).
How to better read scientific articles

The lecture is structured very much as a conversation and I really enjoyed that. At times that meant we didn't cover all of the material for a session, but the professor was awesome about adapting the course expectations according to what was covered. I really appreciated the presence of the teaching fellows. The Zoo trip was a highlight.

Strengths: trip to the Bronx zoo, interacting with skulls of primates, watching videos of primates in action

Weaknesses: teaching style (a little bit unorganized), students expected to answer their own questions

Strengths: Visiting a zoo and seeing primates in action, handling the skulls of primates, analyzing videos of primates. 

Weaknesses: Teaching style is too unorganized and too many tangents, students expected to answer their own questions.

This course is really interesting and presents fun material in a variety of ways. I think that perhaps it could be a bit more organized, but overall it was excellent and I do not have complaints. Eduardo is fun and engaged, and though we can sometimes stray off topic, I really liked the conversations that we had along the way.
A bit disorganized
I think this course was really strong overall.
A lot of the assessment is very subjective- makes it difficult to know how you are doing.

Strengths: Great basis for primatology as a study. Professor and teaching fellows are up to date on the field research and concepts of the course. 
Weakness: Objectives for the midterms could have been posted slightly sooner.
This course would benefit from better TAs.
I liked how the professor encouraged everyone to participate in the process of learning. Every lecture was very engaging.

Strengths, the class is fun, the professor is passionate.
weakness, the class is disorganized, too much irrelevant content.

The material is really interesting and the zoo trip was SO FUN, but the lectures are quite dense. Sometimes it feels like Eduardo is trying to teach the entire field of primatology AND and introductory Ecology and Evolutionary Bio class AND a theory of science class all at once. This makes studying for the tests extremely time-intensive and exhausting because there's so much you "need to know." Also, for a class that is taught by a professor who theoretically puts a lot of value on participation and asking questions, your performance on the tests is 60% of the grade, which seems like a lot.

Some strengths are the focus on students, the use of interesting fieldwork writings, and the compelling topics. Some weaknesses just had to do with technical logistics that could be resolved with some more firm demarcation of what will happen in class or what is expected of students.

The course seems to be a very comprehensive survey of primate studies, so its subject matter would be a strength. Also, lectures were relatively engaging and section was helpful. However, the course staff could work on being clearer about the organization of the course material and about the expectations for homework and exams.
Yes. It's a great way to familiarize yourself with scientific concepts by diving into the interesting world of nonhuman primates.

I recommend this course to people who enjoy learning about things that are not in their typical academic sphere and who want to challenge themselves to learn more about a niche subject. Overall, it is not a curved course and definitely not an easy A as the cut off is at a 95%. This course is designed for non-majors but he will make it very obvious if you are not a non-major.
Yes! It is a breath of fresh air as a course.
I would only take this class if you have a genuine interest in primates and are willing to do all the readings.
Yes! Especially good as a science credit if youre a humanities!
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, especially a humanities student looking for a meaningful engagement with a scientific field.
yes

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. There are very few classes, especially lectures, offered at Yale that have a professor and teaching fellows who are so committed to student learning and making sure that everyone is on the same page whether you are a STEM major or in the humanities. I have already recommended this course to plenty of friends and would highly recommend anyone even remotely interested to check out this class during shopping period. I took this class because I was genuinely interested in the subject but there were so many people who took it for different reasons, so it was also enjoyable having students from very different backgrounds studying the same thing.
Yes. I believe that Professor Fernandez-Duque is a fantastic lecturer with an incandescent intellect.
Yes! Great science class for non-STEM people. I wouldn't say it's a gut, but you can do well if you put in effort. You also learn a lot. Great professor.

I would recommend this course to another student. Because of the way lectures are structured (with high levels of engagement), you will definitely retain information from this course long past the exams end.
Yes, but I'd tell them there shouldn't expect to keep up with all the material.

Probably not. Maybe if you have already taken a few Evolutionary Bio classes and don't need to be learning a lot of theory on top of primate facts. The tests are fair based on the study guides, but the study guides are really long and require several days of work to complete. However, if you are really interested in learning more facts about non-human primates, this is probably a good course for you.
Yes, especially if you find observing primates interesting and need a science credit that isn't math-focused.

I would recommend this course to a student with a specific and particular interest in primates and their evolution because it very effectively covers that subject. I would not recommend this course to a student interested in how that topic relates to humans because that is not covered.
